reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Andama maeaan: Join together to prevent and respond to child labour and child marriage

description.narrative:
The overall objective of the action is to ensure that the protection of children at risk of child labor, Child Marriage, and other child protection concerns in the targeted Governorates is improved through CP response and prevention. The overall objective will be achieved through the combination of 2 inter-related outcomes: Outcome 1 will ensure children at risk benefit from inclusive child protection case management and multi-sectoral services that respond to their needs and contribute to address the root causes of child labor, Child Marriage, and other child protection concerns, including through the capacity building of local civil society organisations (CSOs) Outcome 2 will enhance community and national advocacy to prevent and respond to key child protection concerns - Child labor, child marriage and violence against children - by promoting child participation and empowerment. Under Outcome 1 War Child in partnership with 6 Civil Society Organisations (3 of which will be members of the Child Protection Information Management System (CPMIS) in Jordan) will 1) provide case management for children at risk*, 2) conduct safe identification amp referral of child protection incidents within the existing Jordanian Case Management system (MoSD and PSD or their partners) 3) provide multi sectoral services to children at risk and their caregivers, including group based well-being and learning support for at risk children and targeted support for caregivers, referral to cash economic assistance and/or microcredit program for caregivers of children at risk and 4)conduct community outreach to address the root causes of child protection risks related to individual and community’s perceptions (prevention component). Under Outcome 2 War Child will develop the capacity of and work in partnerships with the CSOs on child led project design and on promoting children’s inputs to local and national level institutions informing improved practices and priorities. Following the capacity development, War Child and the CSOs will collaborate on the formation and empowerment of 2 child boards who will be engaged in child-led awareness raising and community mobilization to bring the voices and perspectives of children on child protection issues such as Child Labour and Child Marriage to community leaders and decision makers. Based on the priorities identified, this trajectory will culminate in a series of child-led community initiatives and outreach toward the MoSD and PSD national representatives and other key actors such as the MoE and MoL, who will be asked to commit to incorporating the input they receive via this initiatives into policy level discussions and decision making.
The roles of the partners will be divided as follows: War Child will provide overall project management and coordination, and will build the capacity of the CSO partners in psychosocial support and learning support methodologies and service delivery and child participation, and support case management supervision and continuity. The CSO partners will be selected during the month of July using War Child partner selection and due diligence process and tools. The selection of the 3 CSOs to lead the case management will be coordinated with the Child Protection Working Group and members of the Child Protection Management Information System in particular, as well as with the MoSD. War Child's Regional Child Protection Advisor, who is a master trainer for case management, will oversee the selection process. The 3 selected CSO partners who are members of the CPMIS will provide case management and capacity building on identification and referral. All 6 CSO partners will lead on community outreach, and provide direct psychosocial and learning support services, and well as conduct identification and referral for case management.
The project will run for 12 months and will be implemented in 6 locations in Amman, Zarqa and Mafraq governorates.
